{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2981951,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T14:59:11.350Z","cooked":"

It seems like every year we get to a point where we want to test a mechanism, like an arm, for the first time, set the PID values to what we think is correct, and hold our breathes when we activate the mechanism in hopes that it doesn’t move out of control and damage something. What things do other teams do during initial testing to limit the potential damage?

In the case of an arm, one thought I had was to create a slip clutch that we initially put on the arm to allow the mechanism to give way if needed. Here is my initial attempt using magnets to hold the plates together. Currently it slips pretty easily, but that might not be a bad thing. I figure I could always add a spring to push the two plates together if needed.

IMG_20211215_2012544074000×2250 1.31 MB

IMG_20211215_2013178722250×4000 844 KB

Video showing it slipping

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-16T15:00:16.862Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":282,"readers_count":281,"score":246.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://photos.app.goo.gl/Ljs7zFN8Pq1zzCbB9","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":30},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/4/74ed2bd250c0f3680129365e26ef262f85ece1dd.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/f/df23ad508fe3f4c5de688fba5ebdeb1ab8c1439f.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2981955,"name":"","username":"mdurrani834","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mdurrani834/{size}/131246_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T15:34:51.762Z","cooked":"

Look into combining a trapezoidal motion profile (also called motion magic for ctre and smart motion in Rev) and PID. Set heavy velocity and accel limits, slowly increase as you go on.

I think this should work, someone should correct me if not.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Trapezoidal Motion Profiles in WPILib

While feedforward and feedback control offer convenient ways to achieve a given setpoint, we are often still faced with the problem of generating setpoints for our mechanisms. While the naive appro...

Also look into physics simulation using wpilib. This is in the docs, is a good amount of work to set up, but is well worth it.

rlance:

What things do other teams do during initial testing to limit the potential damage?

Vacate the death zone and finger over the space bar.

That’s usually it. we die like men or something

rlance:

What things do other teams do during initial testing to limit the potential damage?

Dimensional analysis. A lot of it. You don’t have to worry about the PID loop freaking out and causing damage if you know that the voltages are physically reasonable.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-16T17:26:29.271Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":112.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/4","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981978,"name":"Carlos Gross Jones","username":"CarlosGJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T17:32:01.788Z","cooked":"

For big mechanisms with hard stops (like arms and elevators), we like to write some code to just control the motor throttle directly with a joystick axis, before starting to play with closed-loop. That lets us verify things like sign/polarity and “okay, so 30% throttle makes the elevator barely creep upwards.”

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-16T17:32:01.788Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":166.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Carlos Gross Jones","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning"},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/5","custom_user_title":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981981,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T17:59:31.499Z","cooked":"

Set current and voltage limits in the motor controllers. Start PIDF values at zero, increment them up/down with buttons on a game pad or joystick (usually just P and sometimes I). That’s it.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-16T17:59:31.499Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":73.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981992,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T18:57:50.645Z","cooked":"

Although it’s not a guarantee against damage, using limit switches directly wired into the motor controllers can be helpful in this way. If you can, start with them set well short of the mechanical limits and move them out closer to these once things are working well.

Consider configuring brake mode and temporarily adding cushioning of some type between the hard stop and the point where you have the limit switches. Also, you can set up soft limits in most motor controllers, assuming they have feedback. You should be able to manually test both kinds of limits, even without sending any command to drive the motor.

For pneumatics, you can lower the pressure quite a bit, and/or use a flow control valve.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-17T04:58:32.284Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":54.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981993,"name":"Dan_Karol","username":"Dan_Karol","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan_karol/{size}/227378_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T18:58:50.520Z","cooked":"

My preferred technique is to go through this sequence:

  1. ensure motor direction follows the right hand rule

  2. ensure encoder direction matches the motor

  3. ensure the scaling on the encoder is set to real-world units (inches/mm/deg)

  4. print motor output to the logs (shuffle board or whatever you are using)

  5. manually (without closed loop) use a joystick to apply power to the actuator. go slowly and get a feel for how much power it takes to do the thing. Don’t drive to hard stops.

  6. Use the power observed when moving in step 5 to estimate the slow down distance. I.e. if it takes 80% power to get it to move and there is no coasting then you might want your P-Gain to be somewhere close to 1v/inch or 2v/deg. On the other hand, if it is something like a drivetrain where it moves freely at 25% power then you may want to have a p-gain in the 0.01 v/inch range. You can add in the other terms slowly. usually I and D terms don’t exceed 10% of the P term.

  7. Finally, remove the breaker and command the system to move. observe that the power going to the motor aligns with your expectations as you manually move the mechanism through it’s range of travel.

  8. reinsert the breaker and let it rip (with caution)

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-17T17:53:53.631Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Dan_Karol","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7133,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"131 CHAOS"},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/8","custom_user_title":"131 CHAOS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2982000,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T19:26:19.514Z","cooked":"
rlance:

In the case of an arm, one thought I had was to create a slip clutch that we initially put on the arm to allow the mechanism to give way if needed.

You might find an off the shelf solution like a friction clutch more useful. We’ve used them with arms before (specifically the “Torque Limiters for Chain and Belt Drives” at the top of that page) and they’ve worked great. The torque limit can be manually adjusted (within limits).

When dealing with things like arms that have limited range of motion, my preferred method is to include limit switches at the extremes. Speed controllers can take these as input and automatically stop the motor when the arm hits the limit. It’s not perfect (you still can hit that limit fairly hard!), but it helps prevent the motor from stalling and reacts quicker than a person with their hand over the stop button. You can test those manually, letting you know it works, then move on to your normal PID control!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-16T19:26:19.514Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":35.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Jon Stratis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/friction-clutches/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":20}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC"},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/9","custom_user_title":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2982083,"name":"Wolly :)","username":"wolly_efendi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wolly_efendi/{size}/165245_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-17T02:24:57.348Z","cooked":"

Initially run your loops with a very low scaling factor (say 0.1 or 0.2 depending on friction in the system). After ensuring all motors are running in the right direction at the right times, slowly increase that factor until it gets to 1. Additionally if you are testing a PID you could set a max magnitude the output can’t pass so that things don’t scream through a hard stop. And of course, no one is near the robot and anyone who could be is aware of when it is going to be live. Hand over the disable button. Happy testing

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-17T02:24:57.348Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":26.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"Wolly :)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49878,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2982086,"name":"2582","username":"chadr03","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-17T02:31:23.389Z","cooked":"

This white paper has some great tips.

FRC 6377 The howdy bots just released our first whitepaper! "Dont break your bot a guide for testing large and delicate mechanisms Technical
This whitepaper is a guide on how to test large mechanisms that can fail easily (like arms or elevators) without breaking them it was built with CTREs Talon SRX motor controllers in mind

It is a bit dated and some of the techniques described cannot be performed on an integrated falcon, but still some good info.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-12-17T02:38:05.619Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":116.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398192,"topic_slug":"limiting-damage-when-testing","display_username":"2582","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-6377-the-howdy-bots-just-released-our-first-whitepaper-dont-break-your-bot-a-guide-for-testing-large-and-delicate-mechanisms/367573","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 6377 The howdy bots just released our first whitepaper! "Dont break your bot a guide for testing large and delicate mechanisms","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13827,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limiting-damage-when-testing/398192/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2982108,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-17T04:04:55.983Z","cooked":"

Pretty simple. Start as far away from your target as possible. Comment out your motor set commands (we use a flag set by a controller button combinations on that disables all Motor sets). Have a print, or set a dashboard value with the motor output. That way you can see what motor voltage is commanded. Start with a gain like 0.000001. Take Note Of your motor output, and now you know how many zeroes to remove to get it to move slowly. To start, aim for a motor output no greater than .05

This is where velocity control is nice. When we are coordinating different mechanisms, like a pick, elevator and arm that need to move synchronously, you can set the Max velocity very slow if your doing it in the motor controllers then slowly turn the velocities up once you have them moving appropriately. You can so the same by limiting the pid value to some maximum.

It’s also good practice to do your initial work without the arm attached.
